metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Commentary: The double responsibility of the thoracic surgeon at the time of the pandemic: a perspective from the North of Italy

body_text.text: The rapid spread of the COVID-19 pandemic in the north of Italy at the end of February 2020 10 has taken the local healthcare system by surprise because of exponential increase in the number of daily 11 cases and sheer number of those needed admission to ICUs (1). In the emergency, with hospitals' 12 services being reconfigured, thoracic surgeons still tried to maintain a more or less regular operating 13 schedule amid uncertainties regarding the safety of the patients and healthcare operators (2) (3). 14 Although China was ahead of us in terms of experience there were no data available regarding thoracic 15 surgery and the potential post-operative increase in morbidity and mortality. 16

The first meaningful evidence emerging from this study is the proportion of severe and critical disease 17 between thoracic surgery patients and the whole COVID population that was 27.3% and 36.4% versus 18 2% and 13.8% respectively, strongly suggesting the possibility that surgery, in itself, can negatively 19 affects outcomes. These data seems to be consistent with general surgery (4)(5). This article has certainly the merit to raise awareness of the problem among thoracic surgical 39 community; unfortunately, the small sample size and the heterogeneity of surgical interventions (lung 40 and esophageal cancer, non-malignant diseases) weakens the recommendations that can be drawn. 41

Therefore, although the data presented here are not conclusive, they help to set the basis for a multi-42 centric case series, with identification, on a larger sample, of pre and post-operative prognostic factors 43 that can help surgeons to make the right decisions in this difficult scenario. 44

FIGREF1.text: 20In the present issue of the Journal,Fu et al.  are also to be congratulated as they focus on 21 identifying the diagnostic challenges in the early post-operative management of patients diagnosed with 22 COVID-19 (6). The most important alert is that, in addition to variable incubation period, signs and 23 symptoms of infection often coincide with normal postoperative ones making realistic a delay of about 24 8 and 4 days for suspicious of viral pneumonia and confirmed diagnosis. It should be particularly 25 emphasized that 5/11 cases had misdiagnosis at first postoperative CT scan (7) (8). This implies delays 26 in treatment and greater risk of spreading the infection. We observed a similar pattern, and negative 27 outcomes, in our patients. All thoracic surgeons should be aware that the virus is present in the 28 community way before the official confirmation from healthcare authorities, thus vigilance is 29 mandatory.30 Another important point addressed is the attempt to identify prognostic factors. The main problem 31 remains the relatively poor specificity of blood count and clinical biochemistry changes. On the 32 contrary, significance of the number of resected segments, if confirmed, could be a very precious 33 indicator. Although anatomical lung resections are still the gold-standard for tumors larger than 2cm 34 one wonders if, in the period of pandemic, a risk-comparison between cancer recurrence vs increased 35 mortality due to COVID-19 infection is appropriate and if wedge resection should be consider. 36 These postoperative prognostic factors could be helpful in promptly identifying patients at greater risk 37and rapidly escalate treatments such as pre-emptive ITU admission. 38
